docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 10 The flow of economic aid to Latin America, from major United States Government and international financing agencies reached a record, $1.3-billion, during 1966, according to statistics announced today by the InterAmerican...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 10 The flow of economic aid to Latin America, from major United States Government and international financing agencies reached a record, $1.3-billion, during 1966, according to statistics announced today by the InterAmerican Committee for the Alliance for Progress.
docs.abstract: Inter-Amer Com for Alliance for Progress repts Latin-Amer countries drew $174-million from IMF, '66, repaid $215-million

headline.main: Flow of Economic Aid to Latins At a Record $1.3-Billion in 1966; Long-Term Credits From U.S. and World Agencies Held Sign of Healthy Growth Repayments Also at New High

docs.snippet: This is the first time I step on South American soil. It is my privilege that it should be the land of Artigas [the leader of the Uruguayan independence fight].

docs.snippet: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 11--The new diplomacy of the Americas is informal. Not glittering dinners, but barbecues. Not black or white ties, but plain business suits--even on the Presidential junta del Este generals. Not the historic setting of...
docs.lead_paragraph: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 11--The new diplomacy of the Americas is informal. Not glittering dinners, but barbecues. Not black or white ties, but plain business suits--even on the Presidential junta del Este generals. Not the historic setting of palaces or congresses, but negotiation in the game room of a hotel casino.

docs.snippet: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 11--Unless he  fails to get nine hours' sleep a night, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Lincoln Gordon, can remember almost anything--except jokes.

docs.snippet: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay April 11--The United States and the Latin American nations represented here have found basic agreement on the ways to establish a functioning LatinAmerican common market no later than 1985.

headline.main: U.S.-LATIN ACCORD FIXES TIMETABLE FOR A TRADE BLOC; Presidents Expected to Back Draft for Common Market to Function by 1985 VIGOROUS AID IS SOUGHT Ministers Say That Growth of Business Is Needed as Basis for Integration

byline.original: By BARNARD L. COLLIER Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 11--They came one by one, almost furtively, so that the biggest of them all was virtually sneaking onto the continent whose love  he covets the most. No crowds, no cheers for the Presidents of the Americas--and without...
docs.lead_paragraph: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 11--They came one by one, almost furtively, so that the biggest of them all was virtually sneaking onto the continent whose love he covets the most. No crowds, no cheers for the Presidents of the Americas--and without them the bands and empty artillery rounds were merely routine.
docs.abstract: Johnson in Montevideo; assembles with other leaders amid 'routine' ceremony and no crowds; s briefly; goes to Punta del Este; confs with Pres Diaz Ordaz (Mex); illus; strict security on rd to and in Punta del Este noted; Uruguay bars all popular displays

headline.main: Johnson and Other Chiefs Gather Without Fanfare; JOHNSON ARRIVES WITHOUT FANFARE
